etymology.description: 菜 ‘vegetable’ + 头 ‘head/root end’ = the “head” of a vegetable → radish/daikon.
etymology.interpretation: Literally points to the swollen root or “head” of certain vegetables, hence radish/daikon. Common in Southern Chinese varieties; contrasts with standard Mandarin 萝卜 for radish.
etymology.simplification: 頭 → 头 by standard character simplification, reducing the complex 頁 component and aligning with the productive suffix -头.

examples.chinese: 这家店的腌菜头很好吃(這家店的醃菜頭很好吃)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn de yān càitóu hěn hǎochī.
examples.english: The pickled radish at this shop tastes great.

examples.chinese: 冬天常吃白色的菜头炖排骨(冬天常吃白色的菜頭燉排骨)。
examples.pinyin: Dōngtiān cháng chī báisè de càitóu dùn páigǔ.
examples.english: In winter people often eat white radish stewed with pork ribs.

examples.chinese: 萝卜糕在台湾也叫菜头粿(蘿蔔糕在臺灣也叫菜頭粿)。
examples.pinyin: Luóbo gāo zài Táiwān yě jiào càitóu guǒ.
examples.english: Turnip cake is also called 'caitou kueh' in Taiwan.
